ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How coding intersects with biology and some biology themes; smith waterman algorithm
High level and broad understanding of different aspects of computational biology
I learned a lot about topics in biomedical data science.
I learned about different topics involving biomedical data. I enjoyed the sections on deep learning as it wasn't a topic I was familiar with before.

I mostly developed the skill to write concise paper summaries. During the final project, I learned how to analyze the effects of genomic point mutations on protein structure. However, most of these skills were developed not through class itself, but through self-motivated research and discussions with other students.
You'll get a general overview of bioinformatics techniques and some more theoretical concepts

For MBB/MCDB: Great overview of important bioinformatic topics. Not super in depth, but nice intuitive understanding. This was perfect for me but not what everyones looking for. Great intro to ML and computational techniques for bio majors. The final project also taught me some more applicable skills like working with genomic data, gtex, ensembl, alphafold, etc
A deeper understanding of biology, genetics, proteomics, and data science. Also developed group work skills.

I gained a general understanding of techniques in biomedical computation and about current advances in deep learning and AI. The lectures covered a wide range of topics and discussion sections were useful for delving into papers related to class content. The final project provided an opportunity to apply some of the material from class, where I developed skills in examining vcf files, assessing mutational burden and using pymol.
A broad interview of bioinformatics! Not a lot of skills are taught, like coding. Lots of content.
Methods in biomedical data science
Basic methods in biomedical data science.
Data mining, machine learning algorithms and their application to bio assays.
I gained a broad overview and understanding of the current biomedical advances pertaining to data analysis and machine learning.
A very broad swathe of information covering genomics, deep learning, algorithms, etc.  providing new information to basically all people (bio or stats focused).
Bioinformatics
I learned general principles across a wide range of topics in computational biology.
Very broad overview of many different computational methods including surface level machine learning as it applies to the biomedical sciences.
Methods, issues, and work done in bioinformatics and computational biology.
I learned about a slew of different biological data analysis techniques spanning a broad range of topics and approaches.
I learned about the current research going on in different areas of biological sciences as well as data analysis methods.

I gained a greater understanding of the scale of data analyses in biomedical research, as well as novel computational techniques to extract useful insights from large datasets, or make meaningful predictions about the characteristics of these data sets (machine learning approaches, modeling, etc.)

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think a strength is that you're really allowed to go as deep or not in the learning process as you want. You meet tons of grad students who are really good in the field. I think my TA was really supportive because the TA knew I didn't have a strong bio background .

Strengths: The course is very informational and provides insights into diverse topics. 
Weakness: Topics might be too dispersed that limited time was spent on each topic and fully understanding the material was challenging.
The course is very detailed and I learned a lot from lectures and the homework.

This course covered many different topics which was both a strength and weakness. It was nice because you got to learn about a lot of different fields, but I felt like you couldn't learn much about them since the course was fast-paced.

Strengths: Bigger picture project as a final project, overview of data science methods during class. Also, access to quiz material from previous years was very helpful. Instructors were generally friendly and motivated.
Weaknesses: Discussion sections were useless, as there was no discussion involved. Exercises in homework and quizzes were not explained during class, and no methods were actually taught, but instead briefly mentioned. It would be highly beneficial to connect the discussion sections with contents taught in the lectures. For example, things like backpropagation, kernel functions, Smith-Waterman algorithms etc. could be explained in detail during discussion, rather than having presentations on papers that are not that deeply connected to class material. I had to contact professional computational scientists for help with the backpropagation homework, when really I should have been able to infer the methods for this exercise from class without having to ask professionals. Most students in this class do not have a background in physics or computational science, and so ordinary differential equations are not trivial to them. Therefore, a bit of guidance through approaches asked from us in homework and quizzes would be highly beneficial and I would have learned a lot more in class. Overall, the class tries to include too many topics in one course, and so none of the topics are actually discussed in enough detail to be helpful and understandable. Reducing the amount of content, spending more time on each topic and providing guidance for homework and projects would help this class tremendously.

I think the first half of the course was much better taught and included more useful concepts for the field of computational biology. The second half was largely theoretical and focused on protein structure which was a big shift. I was trying to pay attention but most of the time there were just long derivatives being shown and it was very unclear when or why we would use these practically. I appreciate the diversity in faculty lectures but some of them are just not good teachers and it makes it very difficult to actually learn new concepts. I think I learned most of this course by googling and reading on my own outside of class. 
The workload is also heavily concentrated at a few crucial dates. You have three major assignments in one week (exam 2, final project, and final presentation).

-very good intuitive explanations 
-quizzes are fair and test on basic knowledge. Look at previous quizzes and youll be fine. Homeworks are also fair (bio version) but the second one had some weirdly tedious questions
-guest lecturers are generally great. Personally as a bio major I didnt understand almost entirely the more advanced deep learning guest lecturer and Im wondering what his target audience was
The first reading assignment was a bit tedious but all the others were very useful. The practice exams were great learning aides.

Strengths of this course include the breadth of areas it covers, the professors of diverse backgrounds it facilitates interaction with and the opportunity to discuss relevant papers it provides. However, given the breadth of information, it is difficult to go in depth into any one subject. In the future, it would be helpful if there was more time devoted to fewer key topics, where students could gain practical experience and greater guidance on applying those techniques.
This course NEEDS to have office hours. It covers too many topics too fast. They need to cut down on the number of topics and do a deeper dive for each.
The lectures were difficult to understand for non-data science people.
A little more structure between instructors, and a better system to provide biology background for non-biology students.
I felt like this class assumed too much knowledge about biology/machine learning/statistics.
Strengths: highly organized and able to find lectures and materials easily

The course was well organized and structured. I could easily find all the material on the class website. However, at some points during the semester, there was a lack of communication between the teaching staff and the students. Additionally, the lack of a structured office hours schedule made it hard to find help when needed.
The discussion session can reduce the papers each weak.

The amount of guest lectures was both a strength and a weakness, as it just increased the variance of the course. Some guest lecturers were fantastic and clearly invested in the material, while it felt like others were simply going through the motions. The specific topics being covered are certainly important, but in a survey course like this it's also really important to have a charismatic speaker, as the long-term point is primarily for students to find a few areas of interest and continue to investigate those independently.
lectures are too loose
Strengths: Had a lot of content that was covered. Cons: I don't feel like I have a solid understanding of any particular concept very well unless I came into the class knowing it.
As a large lecture, it does not offer much engagement. Also, the mention of methods is rather fleeting. It should discuss more in-depth about some of the topics.

I think a strength of the course was generally the organization and the topics covered. The topics were interesting, important, and current in the field of computational biology. 

I think the main weakness of the course was how broad and shallow it was. We touched on so many topics that it was difficult to know what was important for the quizzes. I think it would benefit from having fewer topics per unit and focusing more on explaining those topics. I think the lectures could also be more interesting. Some of them lacked enthusiasm and personality which made it difficult to pay attention.
A lot of the lectures in this course were not very engaging nor did they go in depth enough to properly cover the topics addressed during class and discussed on the quizzes.
Too much material; everything was so cursory it felt like we didn't learn much
Strenght: Analysis of real world data
Strength is the breath, weakness is that there was limited background knowledge covered

The course did a good job complementing the scientific course content with discussions of how biomedical data affects societal decisions and problems (for example, a discussion of how personal genomic data can be kept more privately or more securely) -- which conveyed the significance of what we were studying well.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Sort of. There's another evaluation in previous years somewhere saying to "run" away from this course for S&DS majors/certificate holders. I can see why that person feels that way, but honestly just approach this class with an open mind. The TAs are there to help you.
I would recommend it to whoever's interest in the filed of computational biology and seeks a thorough overview of the topics
I would recommend this course to another student interested in learning about how to work with biomedical data.
I would, I think it provides a great overview of biomedical topics and research areas.

No, I would not recommend this class without a strong background in computational sciences and math. The class is more of a general overview lecture, and does not teach how to apply methods for research. Rather, it asks you to perform tasks which were not explained in class, which ultimately leads to you learning more through googling and watching youtube videos than actual class content. The workload is disproportional to credits received, and the deadlines for final homework, project and quiz are too close to one another.

Hmmm, it's one of the very few courses in computational biology that we have so I guess I would say yes. But I think if you don't have a baseline familiarity with certain concepts you will be quite lost - particularly the math foundation for the second half of the course.

Definitely depends on what youre looking for. I personally loved it because as a bio major with very little computational experience I needed a nice broad overview of mining, modeling, learning. It was definitely very interesting for me. Comp people also get a good overview of the wet lab techniques that acquire the data.
Yes, it is a great high level view of several interdisciplinary topics
I would recommend this course if you are looking to gain a broad understanding of computational genomics, machine learning techniques and biomedical modeling.
I would recommend this course as long as you have pre-knowledge of bioinformatics. You need to have strong background in biophysics and biochemistry to succeed in this course.
Its a good course for those interested in having a broad overview of computational biology and bioinformatics.
This is a good credit, especially if you are comfortable with biology and biological concepts. If you are not, you may need to do some reading before taking the course.

I would recommend this course to someone who has a strong background in biology, data science, and statistics. Otherwise, I feel like too much knowledge is assumed to really understand and appreciate the content covered.
Yes, it gives you a good overview of machine learning in the biology application context.
If you're interested in current technological advances in the biomedical/healthcare field, this class is a good survey/overview course.

Make sure you're interested in details of the genome if you're more of a stats person. There's a decent amount of detail there. That said I did learn a decent amount with not that much work (although the weekly summaries added up).
Yeah. An introduction to bioinformatics

I'd recommend the course as an introduction to many topics in computational biology. That being said, due to the amount of topics being covered it's impossible to go super deeply into any one subfield.
it's okay

I would recommend this course - you get to learn a large range of topics in the field of biomedical data and read some pretty interesting papers. The knowledge was hard to process at times when coming from not a particularly strong biology background, but the class was overall intriguing.

Unless you have a computational background, I would probably not recommend it to another graduate student in the biomedical sciences unless your research is going to be somehow bioinformatics based. It is a good overview of a LOT of different topics if you are looking to be introduced into the field of biomedical data science.
If necessary, I would.

I would recommend this course, especially if they are interested in computational biology. The strengths outweigh the weaknesses and its a great review course of what is important in the field right now.

No I would not recommend this course to another student, I felt that the overall engagement by both instructors and students was low. There was little material to reinforce what was taught in class and often the lectures did not touch on the appropriate things at the appropriate depth to account for the varying backgrounds of the students.
No- you don't learn much

I would recommend this course -- it covered many useful concepts that are of growing interest in modern molecular biology and medical investigations (protein structural modeling and deep learning are two examples), while also taking time to stress the human side of large-scale biomedical data and its societal consequences (genome sequencing, privacy, etc.)
